text.p: Lithuanian newspapers carried the following reports in their Tuesday editions. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
ALL NEWSPAPERS

- President Algirdas Brazauskas refused to accept the resignation of the prosecutor general submitted to him in the middle of January. The president and the ruling Homeland Union party failed to come to an agreement on a new candidate.
LIETUVOS RYTAS
- Central European Media Enterprises intends to acquire more than 40 percent of the biggest and most popular commercial TV channel, the Free Independant Channel (LNK).
- After a 57-year break, the Japanese embassy has reopened in Vilnius.
- In Stockholm, Lithuania signed a visa-free travel agreement with Sweden, which comes into force from May 1.
- Inflation in Lithuania in January was approximately three percent, said the executive director of the statistics department Petras Adlys.
RESPUBLIKA
- There are no Eurosceptics in Lithuania, said PM Gediminas Vagnorius during his working visit to Sweden.
- One of the market leaders, Kalnapilis Brewery, decided to triple its share capital to 25.4 million litas.
- Lithuania has received $1.97 billion in foreign credits since 1991. $1.4 billion has been received in the name of the state and $573 million with government guarantees.
LIETUVOS AIDAS

- Danish MP and former foreign minister Uffe Elleman-Jensen, who delivered a speech on integration to Western security structures in Vilnius, urged the three Baltic countries to seek EU memebership together.
- Lithuania celebrates the traditional Shrovetide on Tuesday.
VERSLO ZINIOS
- The results of a tender worth 100 million litas to install 8,000 card pay-phones and switch-boards will be announced at a board meeting of Lietuvos Telecomas on February 13.

- The securities comission registered a new 20 million litas share emission of the Lithuanian Savings bank on January 31. The face value of one share is 100 litas. The shares will be distributed in Lithuania.
- Mazeikiu Nafta refinery has not been working for 10 days now due to crude oil shortages.
-- Riga Newsroom +371 721 5240
